title: UK House price growth hits two-year low
text:
UK House price growth hits two-year low UK House price growth hits two-year low HOSUE prices in Britain grew at their slowest annual pace in two years in June, in a further sign that the market bubble could be bursting. PUBLISHED: 09:40, Thu, Jul 2, 2015 | UPDATED: 11:18, Thu, Jul 2, 2015 GETTY Hosue price growth has slowed 
Values across the country edged by 3.3 per cent over the last 12 months, according to the Nationwide index. At the same point last year the market had registered price growth of 11.8 per cent.And on a month by month basis values actually dipped by 0.2 per cent last month to cancel out a rise of same the amount in May. The average property price is now £195,055, according to the index. 
Regionally, prices in Scotland and Wales fell year on year, by 0.8 per cent and 1 per cent respectively. Related articles Summer Budget 2015: Could George Osborne axe landlord's buy-to-let... 
In London values increased by 7.3 per cent year on year - though the jump is a marked decline from the double digit highs witnessed in recent years. Northern Ireland is now leading growth with annual rises of 8 per cent, but average values in the country are still around 45 per cent below their 2007 peak levels, according to the lender. The typical home value in Northern Ireland is £126,525.Reading and Oxford had the highest increases of any town or city, with price leaps of 13 per cent and 12 per cent respectively over the last year.Robert Gardner, Nationwide's chief economist, said: "The slowdown in house price growth is not confined to, nor does it appear to be driven primarily by, developments in London."Eleven of the 13 UK regions saw a slowdown in the annual rate of growth in the second quarter of 2015."However, Mr Gardner added: "Most parts of the country continued to see annual house price gains - the exceptions were Wales and Scotland, which recorded small declines."A pick-up in annual wage growth, which moved up to 2.7 per cent in the three months to April, means the gap is closing between house price growth and earnings.
